Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Designer polyamide for acid neutralizing personal protective equipment
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to reduce hazardous acid-related injuries of workers who use Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) in mining, the military, first responder service, and other roles. Affected PPE surfaces can still contain the non-diluted acid which may come in contact with skin, leading to injury or disfigurement. This project proposes a new material for the surface of PPE to be chemically reactive so that it can neutralize the hazardous acid on contact. This material may be used as an additive to other materials for chemical suits, lab coats, gloves, secondary containment, and protective coatings. Moreover, this surface can be repeatedly reactivated, enabling sustainability. <br/> <br/>This SBIR Phase I project will advance translation of a solvent-less reactive extrusion. Currently available polymeric and the coatings on the materials that contain the acids act merely as chemically resistant passive barriers and are inadequate. The proposed project conducts a standardized set of experiments to optimize the temporal temperature profile, minimize undesired side reactions, and maximize the throughput. The technical plan includes determination of various parameters to tune product properties. Furthermore, it will be blended as an additive to incumbent PPE polymers to evaluate efficacy.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For decades, in industries like oil and gas, pesticides, food production, and even car washes, workers have been exposed to acids. In 2015, a report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) named hydrochloric and sulfuric acid as two of the top five causes for reported injuries. In response to this ever-present danger, workers are provided with Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and secondary containment, which are resistant to acids. However, resistance is not protection; it only provides a ticking time bomb until injury occurs. The solution provided by safety equipment suppliers is focused on resistance as the best solution to deal with acids. The best product for acid protection has been secondary containment like concrete barriers, plastic containers, acid resistant coatings, and floor mats. Today’s equipment acts only as a barrier, keeping the dangerous acids on the surface, but not eliminating the risk of exposure. Today’s technology that provides resistance can still expose one to acids, especially to our frontline, essential workers who deserve a solution that truly neutralizes the acid threats they face. In the National Science Foundation (NSF) SBIR Phase I grant, Workers First sought to develop a process for an acid neutralizing polymer to help better protect workers from acids in the workplace. When one is exposed to acids, even the most technologically advanced acid resistant materials only provide limited protection for a finite amount of time. While secondary containment reduces the hazard, materials which render an acid spill harmless like those offered by Workers First eliminate it entirely.

In order to solve this problem, Workers First developed its first product, an acid neutralizing polymer material. Workers First initially focused on a manufacturing process, which involved a wet solvent and a batch reactor. This involved a two-step reaction. Unfortunately, this process produced environmentally dangerous fumes. It also required a significant drying process, which continued to contribute to the volatility.

In order to overcome these problems, Workers First aimed to develop a reactive extrusion manufacturing process. Reactive extrusion combines chemical processes and extrusion into a single operation, which is carried out entirely within the extruder. Through the use of a twin-screw extruder, the need for a solvent is no longer necessary as the reactants can be directly mixed into the raw material.

The experiments designed in this proposal decreased the technical risk and facilitated a highly efficient and scalable manufacturing process. In addition, the product produced through reactive extrusion will have optimal acid neutralizing ability. These are a direct consequence of the reaction efficiency of reactive extrusion.

Following this development, Workers First participated in the NSF SBIR Beat the Odds Boot Camp (NSF Boot Camp). From this experience, the unmet need for better PPE for acid exposures was further verified. The different types of personnel involved in these customer interviews were engineers who face this problem daily, salesman having their shoes melted through by the end of a factory tour, lab workers dealing with unknown puddles of acids in chemical storage areas, and even civilians interacting with their local car wash. The common theme among these interviews was the problem of un-neutralized acidic puddles. In order to solve this problem. Workers First developed Neutralmat™, an acid neutralizing floormat. Through the remainder of the NSF Phase I project, Workers First not only accomplished its goal of reactive extrusion, but now proved out the development of Neutralmat™, which would become the first flagship product.

 


Last Modified: 12/13/2022
Modified by: Matthew J Borowiak
